banner.title: TP WorkLife 10/12
banner.mainContentHeadline: The podcast where science meets business
banner.mainContent: From fixing meetings to finding a mentor, get new insights to help you enjoy your time at work and thrive in your career.

videoData.title: Why doctors are offering free tax prep in their waiting rooms
videoData.socialTitle: Why doctors are offering free tax prep in their waiting rooms

recommendations.blurb: More resources curated by Lucy Marcil

recItems.blurb: This three-minute summary of New Jersey's new Earned Income Tax Credit, a state-level credit similar in structure to the federal credit and available to varying degrees in half of the country, describes confusion surrounding tax filing and receipt of the credit -- and makes a compelling case for the need to provide more tax-filing assistance to families.
recItems.headline: "Earned Income Tax Credit Process Confusing for Some"
recItems.label: WATCH

recItems.blurb: On the 40th anniversary of the Earned Income Tax Credit, Senator Sherrod Brown and experts on financial stability discuss the importance of this social policy to create economic mobility and to help families build hope.
recItems.headline: "Earned Income Tax Credit"
recItems.label: WATCH

recItems.blurb: This in-depth documentary series follows children from three families in America struggling with poverty over the course of five years, illuminating the impact of poverty.
recItems.headline: "Poor Kids"
recItems.label: WATCH

recItems.blurb: This compelling book describes the history of social policy in America and its impact on low-income children's opportunities. It also delivers the hopeful message that we can change this narrative if we use policy to increase financial stability for families and children.
recItems.headline: *Child Poverty and Inequality: Securing a Better Future for America's Children*
recItems.label: READ_BOOK

recItems.blurb: Evans and Cassells are developmental psychologists who followed young children living in poverty for decades to quantify the impact of finance on their physical and mental health. The results were stark: different brain structure and function, difficulty with emotional regulation, and learned helplessness. Although cautioning that none of these changes are immutable and that poverty is not a sentence to poor life outcomes, they make a compelling case for the urgent need to address poverty as a health issue. Read more coverage of their work [here](https://research.cornell.edu/news-features/damaging-effects-poverty-children) and [here](http://chicagopolicyreview.org/2013/11/27/enduring-damage-the-effects-of-childhood-poverty-on-adult-health/).
recItems.headline: "Childhood Poverty, Cumulative Risk Exposure, and Mental Health in Emerging Adults"
recItems.label: READ_ARTICLE
recItems.note:
Gary Evans, Rochelle Cassells
*Clinical Psychological Science*, 2013

takeAction.blurb: **Donate** to StreetCred to empower low-income families.

nodes.whoTheyAre: Lucy Marcil is providing fiscal services to low-income families in the doctor’s waiting room.
nodes.whyListen:
Lucy Marcil, MD MPH, creates innovative solutions buffering kids from the adversity they face growing up with economic stress and poverty. As a pediatrician, she cares for children at Boston Medical Center. She co-founded StreetCred, a nonprofit addressing the health impact of financial stress by providing fiscal services to low-income families in the the doctor’s waiting room. StreetCred increases access to critical anti-poverty tax credits such as the Earned Income Tax Credit by integrating tax preparation services into pediatric clinics; it has returned over $3.2 million to 1700 clients at 9 sites in 4 states since its inception in 2016. StreetCred is now bundling tax services with enrollment in other economic mobility services to create greater financial stability.

Internationally, Dr. Marcil has undertaken pediatric health-systems strengthening. As a HIV/AIDS & Community Health Peace Corps volunteer in Namibia, she leveraged public-private partnerships to create a comprehensive orphan care program and girls’ leadership camps. In Bangladesh, she identified community engagement methods to build maternal-child healthcare systems in urban slums. In Kenya, she consulted for Jacaranda Health to transform newborn care systems.

For her work, Dr. Marcil has been recognized with the American Academy of Pediatrics Anne E. Dyson Child Advocacy Award and the Jack Kent Cooke Foundation Quinn Prize, and has been named a Café 100, Davidson College Game Changer and 2018 TED Fellow.

videoData.description: More than 90 percent of children in the US see a doctor at least once a year, which means countless hours spent in waiting rooms for parents. What if those hours could be used for something productive -- like saving money? Through her organization StreetCred, pediatrician and TED Fellow Lucy Marcil is offering free tax prep to parents right in the waiting room, reimagining what a doctor's visit can look like and helping to lift families out of poverty. Learn more about how free tax prep and guidance could be the best poverty prescription we have in the US.

Learn more about how free tax prep and guidance could be the best poverty prescription we have in the US.

cues.text:
How many of you have had
your doctor ask you about sex?
Your mental health?
Alcohol use?
These questions are almost universal.

But how many of you have had
your doctor ask you about money?
Most of us haven't.

But that is strange, because
compared to most high-income countries,

child poverty is an epidemic
in the United States.

It creates conditions that may elevate
stress hormone levels
and impair brain development.

Poor children in the US are one and a half
times more likely to die
and twice as likely to be hospitalized
as their middle-class counterparts.

So my colleague Dr. Michael Hole
and I started asking moms about money.

We knew we needed to reimagine
what a doctor's visit looks like,
to get kids out of poverty

and to give them a fair shot
at a healthy life.

Our questions led
to a surprising solution:
tax credits.

It turns out, the earned income
tax credit, or EITC,

is the best poverty prescription
we have in the US.

The average mom gets two to three
thousand dollars a year from it.

When families get it,
moms and babies are healthier:
fewer depressed moms,
babies weighing more at birth.

But one out of five families
who could get it doesn't,

and most who do
lose of hundreds of dollars

to the for-profit
tax-preparation industry.

One day, a mom asked us
why we couldn't do her taxes
while she waited for the doctor.
(Laughter)

We all know that purgatory.
Why not make good use of that time?
So we started StreetCred,

an organization prescribing
tax preparation in clinics serving kids.
This is a brand-new approach

and one that left some
questioning our sanity.
After all, we're doctors, not accountants.
But we have something accountants don't:
access to families.

Over 90 percent of kids in the US
see a doctor at least once a year.
Their parents trust us

and will do anything
to give them a better life.

Doctors in every clinic around the country
could be doing this work, too --
it's simple, really.

The hospital registers
as a tax-preparation site,

and everyone, from medical
students to retirees,

can volunteer as a tax preparer
after passing an IRS exam.
It's not as hard as it sounds, I promise.

I certainly never thought
I would be doing other people's taxes,
but here I am.
We're nearing the end of our third year.

In the first two, we returned
1.6 million dollars
to 750 families in Boston alone.
This year --
(Applause)

This year, we've expanded
to nine sites in four states.

Sixty-three percent of our families
have never heard of the EITC.

How can you claim something
you haven't heard of?

And half have never used
free tax preparation.
That two to three thousand dollars a year
goes a long way.
Take hunger.

An adequately nutritious, low-cost diet
for a mom and two young kids
costs 477 dollars a month.

With EITC money, that family
can eat for five to six months.
Or think about medical care.

Twenty million children in the US
lack access to care
meeting modern pediatric standards.

And yet, the average cost of that care
is only 400 dollars per kid per year.

EITC money can help fix
this access problem.
Perhaps most powerfully of all,
this money gives moms hope.

One mom used her refund
for her son to study abroad in Spain.
She was struggling to pay her rent,

but she saw EITC money
as his shot at a better future.
We have an opportunity,
as doctors and as citizens,
to get to the root of this problem.
We can reimagine health care

as a place addressing
the causes of poor health,
be it infections
or finances.
Thank you.
(Applause)

footnotes.annotation:
> "But that is strange, because compared to most high-income countries, child poverty is an epidemic in the United States."

For more information, see the University of Michigan's [resources on poverty in the US](http://poverty.umich.edu/about/poverty-facts/us-poverty/), based on US Census and other government data. The UNICEF working paper ["Relative Income Poverty Among Children in High Income Countries"](https://www.unicef-irc.org/publications/655-relative-income-poverty-among-children-in-rich-countries.html) details the US's relative poverty problem compared to its high-income peers.

> "It creates conditions that may elevate stress hormone levels and impair brain development. Poor children in the US are one and a half times more likely to die and twice as likely to be hospitalized as their middle-class counterparts."

It is widely accepted that poverty is associated with poorer health outcomes. The Institute for Research on Poverty at the University of Wisconsin-Madison published a brief, ["Poverty Fact Sheet: Poor and in Poor Health"](https://www.irp.wisc.edu/publications/factsheets/pdfs/PoorInPoorHealth.pdf), that summarizes some of the associations.

Although poverty's impact on brain development is far from fully understood, neuroscientists have found [poverty is associated with different brain development](https://www.theguardian.com/inequality/2017/jul/13/neuroscience-inequality-does-poverty-show-up-in-childrens-brains) in areas associated with learning and executive functioning.

As Dr. David Wood [wrote in *Pediatrics*](http://pediatrics.aappublications.org/content/112/Supplement_3/707) in 2003, poor children have more morbidity and mortality. In 2017, Dr. Andrew Beck and colleagues described [income-based disparities in hospitalizations](https://www.healthaffairs.org/doi/10.1377/hlthaff.2017.1280) in *Health Affairs*. Still others have described disease-specific inequities, such as Dr. Kira Bona’s work in *Pediatric Blood and Cancer* showing [poor children with Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia relapse faster](https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1002/pbc.25928).

> "It turns out, the earned income tax credit, or EITC, is the best poverty prescription we have in the US."

Although many think of food stamps (SNAP), housing subsidies and welfare income (TANF) as the main anti-poverty programs in the US, [Census data](https://www.census.gov/library/publications/2017/demo/p60-259.html), as [described by Dr. Peri Klass](https://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMp1603516), show that tax credits are actually the most impactful anti-poverty program we have.

> "When families get it, moms and babies are healthier: fewer depressed moms, babies weighing more at birth."

Multiple population-based studies have found receipt of the Earned Income Tax Credit is associated with a variety of positive health impacts including [decreased maternal depression](http://ftp.iza.org/dp7261.pdf); [decreased smoking and food insecurity](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/25172139); [decreased prematurity](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/29073507); [increased infant birthweight](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3104729/); [improved child development](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4851995/); and [decreased child abusive head trauma](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5507428/).

> "But one out of five families who could get it doesn't, and most who do lose of hundreds of dollars to the for-profit tax-preparation industry."

As the [IRS describes](https://www.eitc.irs.gov/partner-toolkit/basic-marketing-communication-materials/eitc-fast-facts/eitc-fast-facts), approximately 20 percent of EITC-eligible families nationally do not claim the credit; this statistic varies from 16 to 28 percent [depending on state](https://www.eitc.irs.gov/eitc-central/participation-rate/eitc-participation-rate-by-states). As the [Progressive Policy Institute described in 2016](http://www.progressivepolicy.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/04/2016.04-Weinstein_Patten_The-Price-of-Paying-Takes-II.pdf), the average EITC claimant spends 400 dollars on tax preparation. Both the [IRS](https://taxpayeradvocate.irs.gov/Media/Default/Documents/2017-ARC/ARC17_Volume1_MSP_11_VITA-TCE.pdf) and [The Tax Policy Center](https://www.taxpolicycenter.org/briefing-book/why-do-low-income-families-use-tax-preparers) show that only one to three percent of claimants use free tax preparation despite eligibility for it.

> "Over 90 percent of kids in the US see a doctor at least once a year. Their parents trust us and will do anything to give them a better life."

The Center for Disease Control states that [92.7 percent of children saw a health care professional in the past year](https://www.cdc.gov/nchs/fastats/physician-visits.htm). Before entering public school, children do not go to any other community resource systematically. For example, only [one-third of children under five years old are in regular, non-relative daycare](https://www.census.gov/prod/2013pubs/p70-135.pdf).

> "The hospital registers as a tax-preparation site, and everyone, from medical students to retirees, can volunteer as a tax preparer after passing an IRS exam."

For more information on how to become a free tax preparation, or Voluntary Income Tax Assistance (VITA), site, see the [IRS website](https://www.irs.gov/tax-professionals/enrolled-agents/enrolled-agents-frequently-asked-questions).

> "An adequately nutritious, low-cost diet for a mom and two young kids costs 477 dollars a month. With EITC money, that family can eat for five to six months."

USDA states a "thrifty" diet would cost a family of three [477 dollars per month](https://www.cnpp.usda.gov/sites/default/files/CostofFoodJan2018.pdf). Based on the [average EITC refund of 2,000 to 3,000 dollars](https://www.eitc.irs.gov/partner-toolkit/basic-marketing-communication-materials/eitc-fast-facts/eitc-fast-facts), this money can provide a "thrifty" diet for this family for five to six months.

> "Or think about medical care. Twenty million children in the US lack access to care meeting modern pediatric standards."

Despite insurance expansion over the last few years, the [Children's Health Fund found](https://www.nytimes.com/2016/11/21/nyregion/many-insured-children-lack-essential-health-care-study-finds.html) many children remain underinsured or face barriers to receive standard pediatric care.

> "And yet, the average cost of that care is only 400 dollars per kid per year. EITC money can help fix this access problem."

The Health Care Cost Institute reports [per capita out-of-pocket spending on child healthcare of 472 dollars](http://www.healthcostinstitute.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/05/2016-Kids-Report-5.16.16.pdf).
